channel.title: BBC News - Scotland
channel.description: The latest stories from the Scotland section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Scots unemployment falls by 13,000
item.description: Scotland's jobless total fell by 13,000 to 206,000 between October and December, according to official figures.

item.title: Bridge corrosion problems 'resolved'
item.description: Corrosion problems on the Forth Road Bridge appear to have been resolved, according to the latest inspection reports.

item.title: Tanker drivers to take strike action
item.description: Tanker drivers at Grangemouth oil refinery are to take industrial action at the end of the week in a dispute over pensions and pay.

item.title: Forth searched over missing student
item.description: Central Scotland Police are to carry out a search of the Forth Estuary as they continue efforts to trace a missing teenager.

item.title: Man arrested over Edinburgh death
item.description: A 24-year old man who was discovered with serious injuries in a house in Edinburgh has died.

item.title: Manager Smith exits Dundee post
item.description: Scottish Premier League club Dundee have parted company with manager Barry Smith.

item.title: Man admits raping Scot in Thailand
item.description: A man confesses to raping a Scottish woman who reported being attacked by a group of men in Thailand.

item.title: SNP defends infrastructure spending
item.description: The Scottish government defends its spending on infrastructure after claims ministers have "over-promised and under-delivered".

item.title: Four years prison after knife threat
item.description: A man who forced his way into the home of a Fife woman and threatened her while he was on bail is sentenced to four years in prison.

item.title: Man jailed for child porn images
item.description: An Ayrshire surveyor caught with thousands of child porn images is jailed for three years.

item.title: Report due on high-speed rail line
item.description: The business case for building a high-speed rail link between Edinburgh and Glasgow is to be outlined by the Scottish government.

item.title: Police warning over Gumtree thefts
item.description: Police in Edinburgh investigate a series of robberies of people who agreed to meet buyers for electronics they were selling online.

item.title: Eight-month fire to be extinguished
item.description: A fire which has been smouldering in a pile of wood chips at an Aberdeenshire recycling plant since last June is to be tackled.

item.title: Health board sorry for care failures
item.description: A health board apologises for failures in its care and treatment of a 92-year-old man in the weeks leading up to his death.

item.title: Naked shopper fined after 'prank'
item.description: An Inverkeithing man who walked into his local store naked to buy cigarettes and wine is fined £500 after admitting breach of the peace.

item.title: Four arrested after Rangers v Annan
item.description: Four fans are arrested in connection with an alleged disturbance at Ibrox Stadium during a Rangers versus Annan Athletic football match.

item.title: Fresh row over isles estate buyout
item.description: A fresh war of words breaks out between a landowner and his crofting tenants on Lewis.

item.title: STV sees profits rise and debt cut
item.description: Media group STV increases it profits by 3% and cut its debt and says it has moved on from its dispute with ITV.

item.title: HMV to close 37 more stores in UK
item.description: Collapsed music and DVD retailer HMV is to close a further 37 stores, including branches in Glasgow and East Kilbride.

item.title: Man charged over pensioner robbery
item.description: A man has been charged in connection with the robbery of a woman in her late seventies in Stirling.

item.title: City of Culture 2017 team appointed
item.description: The team to head Aberdeen's bid to become the UK City of Culture 2017 has now been appointed, BBC Scotland can reveal.

item.title: Dolphins 'mimic call of companions'
item.description: Marine biologists at St Andrews University say dolphins mimic the distinct whistles of their closest companions as a way of tracking them.

item.title: Website reveals hidden landscape
item.description: A new website is launched to help people explore an ancient landscape hidden beneath fields and woodland in north-west Caithness.

item.title: Dunfermline share issue 'delayed'
item.description: Dunfermline cancel the launch of a new share issue due on Wednesday but say the offer will go ahead soon.

item.title: Norovirus closes city hospital wards
item.description: Eight out of nine wards at an Edinburgh hospital are closed to new patients due to an outbreak of norovirus.

item.title: School plan receives 12,000 comments
item.description: More than 12,00 people take part in a public consultation into building a new Portobello High School in an Edinburgh field.

item.title: Weir Group in £55m spending spree
item.description: Glasgow engineering company Weir Group makes three acquisitions in three different countries for a total of £55m.

item.title: Clyde Blowers in North Sea move
item.description: Clyde Blowers Capital is poised to move into the oil and gas sector after buying a US energy services business.

item.title: Murder accused 'held Lynda Spence'
item.description: One of the men accused of murdering missing financial adviser Lynda Spence told his former partner he had held her at a house, a court hears.

item.title: Drivers blamed for bridge delays
item.description: Drivers of two lorries carrying abnormal loads are to be reported after being accused of causing delays on the Kessock Bridge.

item.title: Crofters given first refusal on isle
item.description: Residents on Great Bernera have been given until April to decide whether to take over the isle in a community buyout.

item.title: Scotland 'faces EU funding cut'
item.description: Scotland is facing a disproportionate cut in European structural funds thought to be worth about a quarter-of-a-billion pounds, SNP ministers claim.

item.title: Shetland set for £12m budget cut
item.description: Shetland Islands Council is to cut its budget by almost £12.5m next year.

item.title: Peterhead set for new police station
item.description: Councillors are being asked to give their approval to plans for a new police station in Peterhead.

item.title: Campaign planned against footbridge
item.description: A foot and cycle bridge over the River Dee at Braemar is not needed, it is claimed.

item.title: Hospital infection improvements made
item.description: The Healthcare Environment Inspectorate finds improvements in measures to help reduce infection risks at the Borders General Hospital.

item.title: Spending study uncovers failings
item.description: An investigation into the financial management of social work in Dumfries and Galloway uncovers a number of failings.

item.title: Disaster survivor dies 60 years on
item.description: A County Antrim man who was one of the few remaining survivors of the 1953 Princess Victoria ferry disaster has died, 60 years on from the tragedy.

item.title: Falkirk goalkeeper given driving ban
item.description: Falkirk goalkeeper Graham Bowman is fined and banned from the roads after pleading guilty to drink driving.

item.title: Woman, 86, injured in car crash
item.description: An 86-year old woman has been taken to hospital with serious injuries following a car crash in Abernethy town centre.

item.title: Nature reserve plans given support
item.description: Scottish Natural Heritage has given its backing to plans to create a new local nature reserve near Stenhousemuir.

item.title: Meat scandal 'boosting Scots beef'
item.description: Scottish meat sales have increased since the start of the horsemeat scandal because of its reputation for quality, Scots ministers say.

item.title: Universities urge fees cap rethink
item.description: University leaders call for a rethink of plans to introduce a legally-enforceable cap on fees for students coming to Scotland from the rest of the UK.

item.title: 'More work needed' on breastfeeding
item.description: Extra work is needed to encourage more women to breastfeed after a "significant decrease", according to the Scottish government.

item.title: BHP Billiton boss Kloppers to retire
item.description: Mining giant BHP Billiton says its chief executive Marius Kloppers will retire in May, and will be replaced by Andrew Mackenzie.

item.title: Mortgage lending falls in January
item.description: The amount of money lent to UK homebuyers fell last month to the lowest level in nine months, says the Council of Mortgage Lenders.

item.title: 'Wide differences' in child poverty
item.description: Levels of child poverty vary dramatically across the UK and within regions, according to a new map that breaks down poverty rates by area.

item.title: Cross to face Irish for Scotland
item.description: Geoff Cross replaces Euan Murray in the Scotland line-up to face Ireland at Murrayfield.

item.title: Calderwood 'happy' to talk to Dundee
item.description: Jimmy Calderwood says he would be happy to speak to Dundee about their managerial vacancy "if the offer came".

item.title: Johnson hopes for winning feeling
item.description: Interim head coach Scott Johnson is eager for Scotland to improve further in the Six Nations match against Ireland.

item.title: Sgoil Ghàidhlig Ghlaschu a' fàs
item.description: Seann seòmraichean dìomhain gan sgeadachadh airson teagaisg, agus faisg air 700 sgoilear a-nis aig Sgoil Ghàidhlig Ghlaschu.

item.title: Leisgeul mu bhàs eusaintich
item.description: NHS na Gàidhealtachd a' tabhainn leisgeul às dèidh laigsean ann an cùram a fhuair euslainteach aosta a fhuair bàs san ospadal san Ath Leathann.

item.title: Planaichean Chiseòirn gam mìneachadh
item.description: Là fosgailte ga chumail ann an Loch Carrann gus planaichean leasachaidh seann ghàraidh ola Chiseòirn a mhìneachadh don t-sluagh.

item.title: VIDEO: Scottish Parliament
item.description: Minister says a report into the high-speed rail plan for Glasgow to Edinburgh is underway.

item.title: VIDEO: Eddie Izzard: 'I'm 2.8% Neanderthal'
item.description: While using comedian Eddie Izzard's DNA to trace the migration of his ancestors out of Africa and into Europe, geneticist Dr Jim Wilson has discovered that Izzard is 2.8% Neanderthal.

item.title: VIDEO: Cannibal legend hits the big screen
item.description: The story of cannibal Sawney Bean is proving to be hit for a first time film-maker and his family from Aberdeen.

item.title: AUDIO: 'Need to understand' EU funds cut
item.description: Scotland's Deputy First Minster Nicola Sturgeon says she wants to "better understand" why the country could be facing a disproportionate cut in European structural funds.

item.title: VIDEO: Scots SAS soldier's mementoes found
item.description: An insight into the World War II experiences of a Scot who served with the SAS goes on public display for the first time.

item.title: VIDEO: David Hayman on cannibal legend
item.description: Actor David Hayman says he relished the chance to play cannibal Sawney Bean even though the tale terrorised him as a child.

item.title: VIDEO: Bill McLaren memorial unveiled
item.description: Bill McLaren, known as the voice of rugby, is remembered in his home town of Hawick with the unveiling of a memorial.

item.title: In pictures: Yang Guang style
item.description: Edinburgh Zoo's male giant panda bulks up ahead of the mating season

item.title: Emeli Sande: 'Last year was surreal'
item.description: Brit nominee Emile Sande on fame's highs and lows

item.title: Pursuing a financial claim
item.description: Advice on issues such as PPI and credit and debit card purchases

item.title: 'Smelly' fans remind people to eat
item.description: Could a 'smelly fan' help people with memory problems?

item.title: VIDEO: From Nasa to a Scottish bookshop
item.description: One woman's journey from Nasa to a Scottish bookshop

item.title: Your pictures
item.description: A selection of your images taken across Scotland

item.title: Audience plea for TV debate
item.description: BBC's Newsnight Scotland appeals for debate audience

item.title: What the Scottish papers say
item.description: The stories making the headlines in Scotland's newspapers.

item.title: Your pictures from across Scotland
item.description: How to send us your images from across Scotland

item.title: Join Brian Taylor's Big Debate audience
item.description: Join the audience for Brian Taylor's Big Debate each Friday
